Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Demystifying the Engineering and Computer Science Underrepresentation Problem: Understanding the Pathways to and through these Disciplines for Black and Hispanic Women

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many communities are underrepresented in the computing industry. With market demands and equity at the helm, the computer engineering and computer science community has increasingly become interested in broadening participation matters. A more comprehensive understanding of the influences that shape individuals' decisions to pursue computing is essential, especially among Black and Hispanic women. To date, the exploration of Black and Hispanic women in computing is limited, and, in the theoretical and scientific literature, there are very few studies devoted to women of color in computing. The project investigator outlined an exploratory qualitative study that is potentially transformative, examining salient factors that contribute to the underrepresentation of Black and Latino women in computer engineering and computer science. This project is positioned to explore the pathways to and through engineering and computer science for Black and Hispanic women, and the findings have immense potential to render important strategies, solutions, and practices that increase their representation in computing field.

The investigator will conduct in-depth interviews with Black and Hispanic women, using social identity theory and intersectionality as guiding theoretical frameworks Used frequently in science education, engineering education, and other social and behavioral science research, social identity theory and intersectionality will help to pinpoint, interpret, and understand the social complexities associated with being Black and/or Hispanic and a woman in the world of computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed study was positioned to explore the pathways to and through computing (computer engineering and computer science) for Black and Hispanic women. Leveraging prior qualitative research conducted by the PI on the experiences of Black women in engineering industry, this study further examined the unique pathways of women, based on the intersections of race and gender, at an earlier time period (undergraduate) when recruitment and retention efforts can have a greater impact on broadening participation. This work established a better understanding of the factors that contribute to the underrepresentation of women in computer science, particularly Black women and Latinas since a gap in the literature exists with regards to their experiences and influences in computer science.

This proposal was for phase one - a pilot study of an interpretative phenomenological (IPA) inquiry into the experiences of Black and Hispanic women pursuing computing (e.g., computer science, IT, and computer engineering) as an undergraduate degree. The project consisted of in-depth interviews with twelve participants matriculating in a four-year computing degree.

Using social identity theory and intersectionality this study shed some light on the interest and engagement in computer science and computer engineering by listening to their stories on how they choose computing as an occupational pursuit and what their experience have been since they enrolled in computing. 

While the focus of this pilot study was to validate an interview protocol the preliminary findings suggest that friends and family are critical to their engagement and persistence. This finding is problematic since Blacks and Hispanics are woefully underreprsented in computing on all levels. This means that the potential to broaden participation is limited to those few that are already engaged in computing and influencing those in their immediate sphere of influence. However, the pilot study also demonstrated the limited scope of the original interview protocol. Our assumptions have been that their friends are of the same or shared racial, ethnic, and gender identity. In the next iteration of the study we will expand the protocol to probe for questions related to how they meet their friends, how they define friendship, what is the identity of their most influential friends. If it turns out their friends are men of any race or ethnicity, this might be an opportunity to work on developing and influencing allyships within computing to broaden participation. This work expands the scope of work and proved to be the basis for a larger exploration with a more attuned protocol to probe the questions not answered in the original proposed pilot study. 

Intellectual Merit:

To date, the exploration of Black and Hispanic women in computer science and engineering has been limited to popular works and few rigorous research initiatives; Black women and Latinas are largely ignored or unheard in the context of computer science and engineering. This pilot study provided an opportunity to listen, collect, and analyze their stories that yielded insight into the interest and engagement of a population seldom explored.

Broader Impacts:

The results of this study were the basis for a large study in order to transform current views on broadening participation in computer science. The results of this brought attention to the challenges in engaging, attracting and retaining women in computer science as well as challenging our ontological beliefs about what and who are computer science. Long term this work could aid in the advancement of women of color in computer science which has implications on the prosperity of U.S. families and ultimately, U.S. prominence.
